div1.p:
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR
DIES IN HAVANA.

Baltimore Physician Victim of Yel-
low Fever While Making a
Study of Its Germ.

Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, one of the best-known
experts on bacteria and yellow fever germs,
died on Tuesday evening at half-past eight
o'clock at Havana, Cuba. Dr. Lazear had
gone to Cuba for the United States govern-
ment to study and report upon yellow fever
germs, and by a strange turn of fate the
fever was the cause of his death. He was a
native of Baltimore, and had lived for some
time with his family here.

Dr. Lazear was born in the suburbs of
Baltimore in 1866, and was a son of William
L. Lazear and Charlotte Peddigrew. His
grandfather was General Jesse Lazear, for
several years the cashier of the bank at
Waynesboro, Pa., and who also represented
that district in Congress as a Democrat
from 1864 to 1868. At the close of his sec-
ond term he purchased an estate in the
suburbs of Baltimore, called Windsor, and
he died there in 1877.

Dr. Lazear attended college in Washing-
ton, Pa., and after graduating there at-
tended the Hopkins University. He grad-
uated in the class of 1889, after which he
went to New York and entered the College of
Physicians and Surgeons there. He gradu-
ated in 1892 at the head of his class, and re-
ceived an appointment to the Bellevue Hos-
pital in New York, where he served for two
years. After leaving the hospital he went to
Berlin for the further study of bacteria.

In 1895 he was asked to take a position in
the Johns Hopkins Hospital, with special
reference to the study of germs, which he
accepted. In the same year he married
Miss Mabel Houston, of California, whom he
had met when abroad. He made his home
for some time on Park avenue with his fam-
ily. About a year ago Surgeon General
Sternberg, of the United States Army, in-
vited him to take a position on his staff for
work in Cuba for the special study of yellow
fever germs. His family was with him in
Cuba until May last, when they came back
to this country to spend the summer in the
North, being now in Massachusetts. The
deceased is survived by his mother, his wife
and two children--a boy of two years and a
girl of two months. Dr. Lazear was a mem-
ber of the Phi Kappa Sigma fraternity of the
Hopkins.
